item.description:
Game plot

11th century Ireland is at stake. Irish clans and Vikings are competing for power. The island is split up between provincial kings, all of them trying to take the lead by exploring the land and be the first to take control of scarce resources. But no clan is safe from the Vikings who battles and plunder. So, which of the kings will succeed, take control as the High King and proclaim himself ‘Emperor of the Gaels’?

				
				
					About the game

In Emperor of the Gaels you play as a provincial king ruling over an Irish clan. There are 4 playable clans and 8 different provincial kings that can be combined. One of the kings possesses the crown which gives both advantages and responsibilities. Ownership may change during the game.

The game is played over 4 years, starting in spring 1011, and follows a year calendar where season specific events occur. Some of the events are related to farming, for example Sowing and Harvest. Other events are Vikings where the Vikings move and attack, Fair where the clans may trade resources and herds, recruit workers, warriors and chieftains, and Actions where the clans may choose and perform 2 actions chosen from a number of action cards. Some of the actions are related to exploring, exploiting and expanding, for example Explore, Produce and Build. Others give an opportunity to buy development cards or battle and raid against the Vikings. Most of the events and actions are played win parallel which reduces the downtime to a minimum.

Victory points are gained by building up and developing the clan and by defeating and raiding the Vikings. The game ends when one of the clans have defeated one of the Viking towns, a clan has built a round tower or at the end of 1014. The winner is the king who has gathered the most victory points at the end of the game. This king is proclaimed to be Emperor of the Gaels.

Emperor of the Gaels has several challenging mechanisms, for example the dynamic market used for resource trading and the flexible battle system. Together with a variety of combinations of provincial kings, actions, development cards, Viking movements, exploration and battles every game becomes unique.

				
				
					Historical background

Brian Boru c. 941 – 23 April 1014, was an Irish king from the Dal gCais clan who ended the domination of the High Kingship of Ireland by the Uí Néill and probably ended the Viking invasion of Ireland. With a population of under 500,000 people, Ireland had over 150 kings, with greater or lesser domains. Brian first made himself king of Munster, and after subduing the other provincial kings, eventually becoming High King of Ireland in 1002. Unlike some who had previously held the title, Brian intended to be High King in more than name. Brian was described boastfully in both the Annals of Ulster and ‘Book of Armagh’ as: ‘High King of the Gaels’.
 In 1014, Brian’s armies confronted the armies of Leinster and Dublin. The resulting Battle of Clontarf saw Brian killed, but his army was still victorious against the Leinstermen and Norsemen. The battle is widely recognized as a defining moment in Irish history.

The game, while not intended to provide an exact description of history, playfully draws its inspiration from the power struggle, events and situation in early 11th century Ireland.

-description from designer

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable
